awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Biogeochemistry of water and sediments from a recently drained Greenland ice-marginal lake
awd_abstract_narration:
Water melting from glaciers flow on top of, through, and underneath glaciers, ultimately ending up in lakes or the ocean. Sometimes, this water does not take a direct path to the coast, but first enters near-shore lakes next to the glacier, called ice-marginal lakes, which can be dammed by ice. When the ice dams holding the water in these lakes fail, the water can rapidly drain to the coast over several days. The largest ice-marginal lake in Greenland is believed to be Lake Tininnilik, which recently drained into the ocean in 2021. The current low water levels mean that sediments in the lake are now exposed. This will be the first study to measure chemicals, nutrients, and microorganisms in the lake and sediments. It will also determine how lake storage changes the chemistry of water melting from the glacier. With continued climate warming, the amount of water stored in ice-marginal lakes is expected to increase, and determining the chemistry of Lake Tininnilik is important for understanding ecosystem change and carbon cycling in the coastal ocean following drainage. The project leadership includes three women, all of which are ethnic and racial minorities. As part of this project, a web-based virtual reality tour of Lake Tininnilik will be created for anyone to use. The tour will be important for other scientists trying to better understand the layout of the lake and will also be a teaching tool for the public. 

Because of erosion and weathering under ice sheets, subglacial waters are rich in macro- and micro-nutrients. These nutrient-rich waters can be directly discharged into the ocean or stored in pro-glacial lakes, including ice-marginal lakes. Lake Tininnilik is a large ice-marginal lake restrained by an ice dam along Sarqardliup Glacier in western Greenland. It drains approximately every 10 years into a local fjord, most recently in 2021, exposing previously inundated sediments. Preliminary work prior to the 2021 drainage shows that iron (an important minor nutrient for marine phytoplankton) is 10 to 100 times greater than glacial meltwater entering the ocean directly. The iron concentrations are also paradoxically high compared to other redox sensitive element concentrations. This project will collect and analyze water samples from different lobes of Lake Tininnilik and exposed sediments to address how ice-marginal lakes change the chemical and microbial composition and availability of nutrients for near-shore and open-ocean ecosystems. Sarqardleq Fjord, into which Lake Tininnilik drains, is an important source of fish for local indigenous populations, and this work will aid future studies seeking to understand how rapid drainage events may affect the marine food web.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Worldwide, ice sheets and glaciers are melting and shrinking faster and across more areas than ever before due to global warming. The increased amount of meltwater pouring off from the edges of ice sheets and glaciers ultimately ends up in the ocean, leading to big global impacts such as sea level rise; freshening and weakening of important ocean currents; and changes in the global carbon cycle.  Temperatures in the Arctic are warming four times faster than the global average, so ice is melting even faster there than in most other places. Our project was focused on better understanding some of the ways in which meltwater from the Greenland ice sheet, the only remaining ice sheet in the Arctic (and the second largest ice sheet on the planet) may alter the chemistry and biology of the surrounding ocean, from nearby fjords out to the North Atlantic Ocean. 

Most Greenland runoff starts as pools of pure snow and ice melt on the surface of the ice sheet. These pools can combine forming streams which find cracks and holes through the ice to plunge to the bottom of the ice sheet. There, these streams join even larger raging rivers that wind their way under the Greenland ice sheet ultimately pouring out on the coast. Along the way, this water is transformed through biological and chemical processes during its interaction with its surroundings, in with particular rocks, sediments and groundwater underneath and next to the ice sheet. Understanding the kinds of pathways and over what timescales meltwater travels is important to knowing what its impact will be on the marine environment.  The goal of this project was to examine in closer detail the biogeochemical nature and processes occurring in ice marginal lakes, one of the more complicated and poorly understood glacial meltwater pathways.  

Thousands of Ice marginal lakes have been found all around the edges of the Greenland ice sheet, and they are a common but yet poorly understood feature in many glaciated regions, including Greenland.  These lakes receive freshwater input from a combination of subglacial, supraglacial, terrestrial and meteoric (eg rain and snow) sources, building up in size over years to decades. A subset then periodically drain, sometimes catastrophically resulting in the rapid discharge of large volumes of water downstream via glacial lake outburst floods (or GLOFs) in a matter of days to weeks. In some cases these GLOFs can deposit large amounts of sediment, nutrients, and freshwater directly into coastal waters and fjords. For this project we visited a recently drained lake, Lake Tininnilik, in west Greenland. Lake Tininnilik is one of the largest (~40 km2) ice-marginal lakes in Greenland and during cyclic (quasi-decadal) catastrophic drainage events, up to ~2 km3 of water from Lake Tininnilik is discharged directly into Saqqarleq Fjord and ultimately Disko Bay. We analyzed water samples collected from glacier runoff and streams around the lake as well as water on the surface and at depth in the lake.  We found that Lake Tininnilik receives approximately 80% of its water from the subglacial-glacial environment, with the remaining smaller fraction coming from terrestrial streams and groundwater. We also found that this system is overall nutrient rich, particularly in iron, an important limiting nutrient in marine ecosystems. Saqqarliup Glacier represents a very small part of the Greenland coastline, yet the fluxes of nitrogen, phosphorus, silica and iron from a single rapid drainage of Lake Tininnilik represent an exceptionally large fraction of the total annual subglacial nutrient discharge across Greenland. These results indicate that ice-marginal lake outburst floods are a previously unrecognized yet significant source of nutrients to Arctic coastal waters and have important subsequent implications for fisheries.  This project supported an early career scientist, to date results from this project have been presented to scientists through seminars and at conferences, and a virtual tour of the study site introducing the project is also available for the public at https://virtualice.byrd.osu.edu.
